body_html:
@VinceMarron huh, so I haven't used Eager mode with a GPU, but I think that error is saying your signal tensor is not located on the GPU, while the op Shape (which is part of the subgraph created by tf.contrib.signal.frame) expected that it was.

Can you try the advice in the error of putting .gpu() on the end of your definition of signal to explicitly copy it to the GPU? Or maybe define signal within the with tf.device('/gpu:0'): block.
body_text:
@VinceMarron huh, so I haven't used Eager mode with a GPU, but I think that error is saying your signal tensor is not located on the GPU, while the op Shape (which is part of the subgraph created by tf.contrib.signal.frame) expected that it was.
Can you try the advice in the error of putting .gpu() on the end of your definition of signal to explicitly copy it to the GPU?  Or maybe define signal within the with tf.device('/gpu:0'): block.
body:
@VinceMarron huh, so I haven't used Eager mode with a GPU, but I think that error is saying your `signal` tensor is not located on the GPU, while the op `Shape` (which is part of the subgraph created by `tf.contrib.signal.frame`) expected that it was. 

Can you try the advice in the error of putting `.gpu()` on the end of your definition of `signal` to explicitly copy it to the GPU?  Or maybe define `signal` within the `with tf.device('/gpu:0'):` block.
